Indian retail gets stronger with the reformed FDI policy

2019 saw some of the most positive changes in India's retail scenario with policy reforms that have proved Government's commitment towards making the country a favourable and attractive sourcing as well as retail destination. In August this year, India relaxed local sourcing norms for single brand retailers with foreign direct investment (FDI) and allowed them to sell online even before setting up physical stores. The move is expected to benefit some of the largest global retailers including IKEA, H&M and Uniqlo. Prior to the reform, for singlebrand retailers with over 51 per cent FDI, the policy required 30 per cent of value of goods to be procured from India as part of the local sourcing requirement. However, the new policy maintains that all procurements made from India by a single-brand retailer for that brand shall be counted towards local sourcing, irrespective of whether the goods procured are sold in India or exported. Furthermore, the Government has decided that sourcing of goods from India for global operations can be done directly by the entity undertaking single-brand retail or its group companies (resident or non-resident), or indirectly by them through a third-party.



Moreover, brands now applying for FDI in single-brand retail will also be allowed to commence e-commerce operations even before they set up physical stores, subject to the condition that the entity opens bricks-and-mortar stores within two years from the date of start of online retail. The reformed policy is making a big difference in terms of bringing investments in the sector, employment and growth. This will also dramatically increase the export capability of the country. The FDI policy has been lauded throughout the year by global brands like IKEA, Uniqlo, etc. even as these brands continue to work towards increasing their sourcing from India.

The reform policy was also welcomed by Kumar Rajagopalan, Chief Executive Officer, Retailers Association of India (RAI), who appreciated the Government's stance on contract manufacturing. "FDI in contract manufacturing is also a good move as it can encourage new types of manufacturers to look at India seriously. The easing of the channel pays for single brand retailers by allowing them to start off with online and then subsequently go offline and is also a laudable change as it increases ease of doing business and will encourage them to come to the country."

With an escalating trade war between the US and China, the opening up of contract manufacturing is bringing about certainty for companies who were seeking to set up an alternate manufacturing hub in the country. Prior to this, India had no specific provision for contract manufacturing in its FDI policy.

As per a report by Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT), FDI equity inflow in India in 2019-20 (till August) stood at US $ 19.33 billion. India received US $ 2.73 billion of foreign investment in the month of August 2019 as compared to US $ 2.54 billion in the previous year.

International firms clawing their way into the Indian market

Today, India is one amongst the fastest growing retail industry in the world and is increasingly becoming the focal point for some of the largest global retail firms. An enormously growing middle-class population with ever increasing disposable income, powerful manufacturing sector and strong economic fundamentals have made the country an important destination for international brands to have their strong foothold in. The Indian middle class is forecast to expand at 19.4 per cent per year, outpacing China, Mexico and Brazil. In fact, McKinsey Fashion Scope had maintained at the beginning of this year that 2019 will be the year in which India will take centre stage and that more than 300 international brands are expected to open stores in the country in the next two years.

According to data from McKinsey's Fashion Scope city-level growth forecasting tool, India's apparel market will be worth US $ 59.3 billion (about Rs. 4.12 lakh crore) in 2022, making it the sixth-largest in the world and comparable to Britain's US $ 65 billion (Rs. 4.51 lakh crore) and Germany's US $ 63.1 billion (Rs. 4.38 lakh crore). It's just not the figures that say so, but also the continuously increasing interest of some of the biggest international retail firms in the Indian market and their continuous expansion and fund infusion in business here. Walmart, which bought India's largest online firm Flipkart Group, last year for US $ 16 billion, has been infusing funds and working on growing its India business, throughout the year. In fact, infusion by both Walmart and Amazon in India in the whole of this year has been phenomenal and worth mentioning.

The online retail giant Amazon had recently announced its plan to roll out more than 100 kiosks in malls across the country by the end of the year. The company experimented with its first kiosk two years ago in Bangalore and has been operating four of them in the country. In June, this US-based retail giant stepped up its investment in its Indian marketplace and pumped in Rs. 2,800 crore. It had infused Rs. 2,200 crore into its Indian business just six months ago and has so far spent upwards of US $ 5.5 billion. Amazon India allotted 2.8 billion equity shares of Rs. 10 each aggregating to Rs. 2,800 crore at par on rights basis to the existing shareholders of the company, according to the regulatory documents filed by Amazon. The resolution for this capital infusion was passed by the board of directors of Amazon Seller Services on 21 May. Again, after filing its annual performance report for the financial year ending March 2019, Amazon decided to invest Rs. 4,472.50 crore (US $ 630 million) in three of its Indian businesses - Amazon Pay, Amazon Retail and Amazon Sellers Service, according to business intelligence platform Paper.vc. The retail giant's main rival is Walmart owned Flipkart and the recent funding is expected to help the firm take on its opposing party. Jeff Bezos, Founder of the retail giant, had committed investment worth US $ 5 billion in the Indian market in 2016.

Amazon and Flipkart have been investing millions of dollars across various operations as they are looking at strengthening their position in the Indian e-commerce market. For its festive season sale, Flipkart brought onboard nearly 27,000 kirana shops across 700 cities to strengthen its pan-India supply chain in order to enhance e-commerce experience for its existing 160 million customers. Flipkart had received Rs. 1616.12 crore in capital infusion from its Singapore-based parent company called Flipkart Pvt. Ltd. in September, according to the documents filed with Registrar of Companies (RoC). Before this, the Singapore entity had injected Rs. 1431.3 crore in Flipkart India in January this year. Flipkart India has allotted 4,64,403 equity shares to its Singapore parent entity at Rs. 34,800 per share that includes a premium of Rs. 34,799 on each share.

So, while these two online retail giants are competing for a better presence in India, a number of other foreign brands have entered the country in 2019 courtesy the growing retail industry in India. For example, Uniqlo from Japan, Hummeland Ecco from Denmark, Yoyoso from China, among others.

Reliance is gunning for top slots in the Indian retail scenario

India's biggest conglomerate Reliance Industries Ltd., has been hankering to reach the top in every industry it lays its eyes on. Led by Mukesh Ambani, Reliance has found footing in retail unlike any other with its respective subsidiary, Reliance Retail's fashion and lifestyle retailing business crossing the Rs. 10,000 crore milestone in 2018-19. This is despite the slowdown of business from 10.3 per cent of total sales in FY '18 to 8.4 per cent in FY '19. Accordingly, Reliance Retail's fashion and lifestyle retail business revenue in 2018-19 was Rs. 10,967 crore as compared to Rs. 7,127 crore in the previous fiscal.

The growth in the business comes as no surprise to any one who is associated with the industry, seeing the pace at which the company has invested in and acquired ventures across platforms.

The first quest to strengthen its readymade garments and accessories portfolio in the fashion and lifestyle retail space came with the acquisition of diversified conglomerate ITC's mid segment menswear brand, John Players.

Reliance acquired the assets of John Players, which includes the brand and distribution rights through 750 stores. This is expected to have added Rs. 350 crore to Reliance Retail's value fashion business carried out through Reliance Trends and Ajio.com.

Reliance Industries is not only interested in established brands but seems to consider the start-up space as one to watch out for. In August this year, the behemoth acquired a majority stake in Google-backed fashion portal Fynd, which hints towards Reliance's increasing ambitions in the e-commerce sector. As a part of the deal, RIL bought 87.6 per cent stake in the company for Rs. 295 crore as it aims to push for online-to offline (O2O) commerce.

In one of the biggest acquisitions of the year, Reliance bought Hamleys for about Rs. 620 crore (GBP 67.96 million) in an all-cash deal. Not only this, the conglomerate has set out to help some of the biggest brands open their doors to the Indian market. As per reports, the prestigious Tiffany and Co., as well as the popular home goods retailer Pottery Barn will be unveiling multiple stores across the country in the near future.

Italian luxury house Versace and Valentino have been on a lookout for a new partner in India and Reliance seems to be the top contender to take over the India franchisee rights and sell authorised products, adding more names to its already vast portfolio of luxury and premium brands.

Reliance Brands is also looking to expand Italian denim brand Replay in India, in less than a year after it acquired the distribution rights for the premium fashion label to be sold in Indian markets. The brand will open doors to almost 10 stores by the end of 2021, joining the league of brands such as Calvin Klein, Diesel and GAP

In the next five years, Reliance is aiming for a fivefold growth of its fashion retail stores in India. From the current 557 Reliance Trends outlets spread across 160 cities, the company plans to take the tally to 2,500 stores in 300 cities by 2023. Reliance Retail is also working on an omnichannel strategy to integrate its offline retail stores with its online business. It is for this reason that Reliance has been withdrawing its clothes, shoes and lifestyle products from would-be rival marketplaces like Amazon and Flipkart. It aims to shift focus to its own portals.

Reliance Industries has the highest number of global fashion and lifestyle brands in the country with around four dozen joint ventures or master franchisee arrangements with international labels including Diesel, Kate Spade, Steve Madden, Burberry, Canali, Emporio Armani, Furla, Jimmy Choo and Marks & Spencer.

Government calls for 'Start-up India', international players get attracted

India's coveted start-up club of unicorns - firms valued at US $ 1 billion or more, are growing faster than ever. 2019 alone has produced over half a dozen unicorns so far, 8 to be precise. Homegrown ventures have managed to garner US $ 7.67 billion in the nine-months ended 30 September of 2019. Holding the position of the third largest hub of startups in the world, the Indian Government has taken upon itself to enable every enterprising entrepreneur to succeed in his endeavour. While announcing a start-up friendly Union Budget in July this year, the Government made its agenda clear of addressing the issues of unemployment and reviving the ailing economy which necessitated building confidence of start-ups and SMEs through reforms and policy amendments in their favour. India has seen the rise of over 40,000 start-ups, which have created more than US $ 130 billion of value from January 2014 to September 2018. In such an exciting phase of the Indian economy, Union Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has emphasised on push for start-ups, mudra loans for up and coming entrepreneurs and also easier approval system to create companies, which has been lauded by the overall start-up ecosystem. To delve deeper into what the budget has brought for the Indian start-ups, the Finance Minister has begun the process of clearing the tax issue which mostly discourages discerning entrepreneurs from turning their ideas into businesses. According to the announcements, start-ups and investors filing necessary declarations are no more constrained by any kind of scrutiny with respect to the valuation of the share premium and the funds raised by the start-ups are no more subject to undergo the scrutiny of the Income Tax Department. Also, income tax assessing officers need to obtain prior approval from their supervisory officers before conducting an inquiry or verification of the income tax return filed by the start-ups.

Furthermore, the announcements also ruled that the start-ups funded by Category-II Alternative Investment Fund (AIF) are now exempted from angel tax and they no longer will be questioned where funding exceeds the face value of shares, as under Section 56(2)(viib). Keeping in line with this, the Ministry of Corporate Affairs also said that it will allow start-ups to issue 50 per cent of their paid-up capital as sweat equity. The period of exemption from other regulatory filings which was 5 years has now been extended to 10 years. According to the DPIIT, ventures will come under the definition of start-ups for up to 10 years from their date of incorporation. A notification will be issued to inform start-ups of the proposed changes. Even as most of the start-ups that started operations have held solid ground, once popular names likes Buttercups (an online lingerie retailer) and Stalk Buy Love, women's fashion apparel portal have fallen prey to tough market conditions and lack of funding.

While these and many other measures by the Government are making India a favourable market for growth of startups, they are also attracting a number of international online firms to the country. However, these firms started doing business in the country through illegal ways which later led to the seizure of around 500 of their parcels by the Mumbai Customs. Many e-commerce firms from China were shipping goods ordered by Indians to various cities claiming they were 'gifts'. As per the domestic laws, any gifts received by Indians up to Rs. 5,000 don't attract any taxes. After the Government's clampdown on Chinese e-commerce companies and sellers who were allegedly sending goods to India as gifts to evade duty, these firms are now working towards establishing their bases in India for smoother functioning. Shein which entered India in 2017 has invested Rs. 250 crore for marketing in India and has localised its customer service, logistics and marketing efforts in the country. Shein has attracted more than 3 million followers on social media and collaborated with about 2,000 influencers and received about 20,000 orders a day.

India going for no-ownership trend

Sharing economy is the new in-thing in India and as per a research, by 2025, it is estimated that many areas of the sharing economy will rival the size of their traditional counterparts. This has evolved in such a way that sharing model has become a default choice for younger consumers in the society. While categories like real estate, furniture, automobiles, etc. have been excelling in this model, clothing and accessories segment is now taking up the market by storm and it makes perfect sense for people who cannot afford luxury brands but do appreciate the intricacies and quality. According to a report by Allied Market Research, globally, online clothing rental market size is estimated to reach US $ 1,856 million by 2023, growing at a CAGR of 10.6 per cent from 2017 to 2023. And this is estimated to grow at a much faster rate in India. The online fashion rental market in India, pegged at US $ 3-4 billion, has been expanding continuously with a number of existing players as well as start-ups like Flyrobe, Stage3, The Clothing Rental, Liberent, among others, which are extensively attracting seed funding.

The industry has seen immense potential which is also proven by the very recent acquisition of Flyrobe by New Delhi based start-up AARK World Pvt. Ltd. that owns and operates fashion rental service platform Rent It Bae. The merger of the two businesses will now operate under the brand name Flyrobe. The deal is aimed at accelerating growth and expansion. The company plans to expand its footprints in India and overseas in Dubai, London and the US through a franchise model. The firm is also launching virtual walls at all Flyrobe stores. Within months, the trial feature with Augmented Reality will be available on its mobile apps as well, which would be called 'Tryrobe'. This technology will be the first of its kind in the ethnic fashion space. The company plans to incorporate an omnichannel strategy to grow the business as consumer demand for a multichannel shopping experience continues to mount.

The year ruled that fast fashion is not a sustainable practice as it is and to top it, the shopping behaviour of today's millennials has changed drastically wherein they need a new garment for every occasion. And this has led to rise in rental market in developing economies of Asia-Pacific as they are looking for an economical alternative to direct purchasing every time. On the same lines, a number of brands - both national and international - are embracing the concept of circular economy. Swedish fast fashion brand H&M is the latest player to show its commitment to a more circular version of the fashion industry with its new rental, repair and recycling concept in its H&M Sergels Torg store located in Stockholm. Re-commerce is another term to the otherwise known resale industry and this too is attracting a number of millennials and generation Z population across the world. Re-commerce retailers are growing 20 times faster than the conventional retail market and 5 times faster than discount retailers, according to Coresight Research.

On a lookout for newer strategies amidst retail downsizing and bankruptcies

2019, a year that has been packed with surprises, has also relayed many shocks to those who have had to bid adieu to some of their favourite brands. Thanks to the rapidly changing consumer trends and mounting competition from e-commerce players, traditional bricks-and-mortar retailers and brands are forced to shutter stores at rates that have never been seen earlier.

By this November, retail store closures were already nearly 55 per cent higher than during the entirety of 2018. That's according to advisory firm Coresight Research, which put the number of closures at more than 9,000 as of 1 November.

Names that were once etched in minds as the most popular shopping destinations have declared bankruptcy, despite various attempts to restructure and stay afloat. The most distressing were the Chapter 11 filings by Forever 21, Barney's, Payless, Diesel among many others. Some brands, however, have downsized considerably in order to decrease expenses in the day and age of rising costs. JCPenney, Gap, Sears and Victoria's Secret are just some of the names that are in the process of effecting a turnaround.

However, the US $ 1.5 trillion apparel industry is one that companies continue to keep vying for. In an attempt to gain a piece of that pie, quite a few stellar international companies have collided with the world of fashion in the form of unusual collaborations.

Although the year has been a tough one for retail in general, the apparel and fashion industry continues to be a force to be reckoned with. The United States' apparel market alone is expected to grow from US $ 350 billion in 2015 to US $ 385 billion in 2025, that projects a CAGR of 2 per cent, according to Statista.

Pepsi marked its entry into the fashion world through a collaboration with homegrown ready-to-wear label HUEMN. The collection which was designed by designer duo Pranav Misra and Shyma Shetty was launched at Lotus India Fashion Week S/S '20.

The company has made a conscious effort to make the collection as sustainable as possible with all the denim fabric used being made with recycled plastic. The collection consists primarily of athleisurewear and is a step forward for PepsiCo's 'Winning with Purpose' vision which aims to build a world where plastics never become waste.

Another brand foraying into collaboration is Italian sportscar maker Ferrari. It has collaborated with Italian luxury house Giorgio Armani. Not only fashion, the brand is aiming to diversify into entertainment and luxury services as well, looking to garner 10 per cent of its EBDIT within the next decade from these categories. Ferrari's new direction in branded goods means items like parkas and sunglasses will now carry premium-style pricing more, keeping up with the image of the company's sports cars.

Tommy Hilfiger has taken a leaf out of its history book by revisiting the first Coca-Cola Clothes collection that it created in 1986. Celebrating that iconic milestone, Tommy Jeans launched the re-edition of the styles as Tommy Jeans Coca-Cola capsule collection in collaboration with the popular beverage conglomerate.

Shake up at the top management level

As some brands are tirelessly working to revamp their companies in order to gain traction in a declining market, others have had to bear the loss of a brilliant leader.

One of the most disheartening blows to the e-commerce world was the resignation of Jack Ma, the Founder and Executive Chairman of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba. Being known for his playful image and quirky antics for motivating his employees, Ma has been able to leave behind a legacy that will break the pattern of wobbling share prices and overall downturn of big tech companies when their charismatic leaders take their leave.

The record-breaking sales of US $ 38 billion on the recent Singles' Day sale held on 11th of November 2019, is a testament to how the company continues to flourish on the strong foundation he laid. The sales saw a 26 per cent rise from last year's GMV.

Alibaba's secondary listing in Hong Kong became the world's largest offering in 2019, larger than the roughly US $ 8 billion raised by Uber in May. The company is looking to issue 500 million new ordinary shares which are likely to raise HK $ 88 billion (US $ 11.3 billion) before a so-called 'green shoe' over-allotment option that will have 75 million more shares. This option could take the total to US $ 12.9 billion.

2019 came as a year for one of the biggest losses to the fashion industry with the death of fashion maven Karl Lagerfeld. The creative director of iconic brands such as Chanel, Fendi and his own eponymous label, Lagerfeld was one of the most famous, outspoken, and influential figures who helped make Paris the fashion capital of the world and shaped the luxury behemoth, Chanel over the course of 36 years. Following his demise, Virginie Viard took his place, having been his right-hand woman since 1987.

Another popular brand facing its fair share of struggles this year that were offset by something other than the 'retail apocalypse', is Ted Baker. Ray Kelvin, Founder and Chief Executive of Ted Baker stepped down amid allegations of sexual misconduct related to forced hugging by business colleagues. The news made the first-half results swindle with the company shares plummeting as much as 38 per cent.

Lindsay Page was entrusted with the reigns of the company thereafter, and a string of new executives, including former ASOS People Director Peter Collyer who joined as the Chief People Officer, have come on-board to overturn the current slump. The company also poached industry veteran Rachel Osborn to be the Chief of Finance after having held the same position at department store chain Debenhams for a year.

Overall, it has been a year of shuffling of the top management of well-known brands. Gap Inc. announced that CEO Art Peck, who took on the role in 2015, will be stepping down. The news caused the company's stock to plummet 7 per cent to US $ 16.75. The son of Founders Donald and Doris Fisher, Robert J Fisher, who serves as Gap's Non-executive Chairman of board, will be taking over the position as interim CEO and President.

The Founder of Superdry, Julian Dunkerton has become the British retailer's permanent CEO after emerging victorious in a bitter battle for control in April wherein he prompted the existing directors, including Chief Executive Euan Sutherland, to resign en masse.

JC Penney Co. Inc. hired James DePaul, Former Chief Administration Officer and Senior Vice President of stores and operations at Shopko and a 25-year veteran in the industry.

An appointment that is taking the fashion world by storm is that of Tom Ford as the Chairman of the Council of Fashion Designers of America (CFDA). After taking over from Diane von Furstenberg earlier this year, Ford introduced a slew of changes ahead of the New York Fashion Week S/S'20. One of his first moves was to make the board more diverse by including younger designers, especially those of colour, who have been making their mark on the industry. The other move was introducing a shorter schedule for NYFW.

Body positivity and inclusion remained buzzwords in 2019

Fashion was always meant to be a form of self-expression but that was confined only to the skinny, white girl. This industry is fast realising the necessity for inclusion of not only people of colour but also people across sizes.

This year, a lot of brands have stepped up their game to show that they are not far behind in the race for inclusion. Dolce & Gabbana unveiled garments that range up to size 54 in Italy, the approximate equivalent of a stateside size 18-20. This move by the Milan-based brand to extend its sizing, which went into force with its pre-fall collection, makes it the first first luxury fashion house to extend its size range to 20 in the US, 22 in the UK and 54 in Europe women.

There is hardly anyone in the fashion industry who is not familiar with Agent Provocateur, the supremely sexy and luxe lingerie brand launched by Serena Rees. However, Rees set out to venture into a unique concept with her modern and inclusive intimates and street wear brand Les Girls Les Boys. The brand will offer gender fluid underwear, i.e., pieces that are unisex and can be worn by both men and women.

Not only are brands trying to bear in mind to break stereotypes that have been held up for ages on, even ramps are becoming more inclusive. In February, of the 7,300 models who walked in 221 shows, about two of every five cast were persons of colour. That's a 38.8 per cent increase from spring 2019's findings. From Nike introducing plus size mannequins, Sangalese model Khoudia Dio who became an internet sensation overnight for her strikingly dark, glistening skin and Trans model Stav Strashko have walked the runway for Marc Jacobs and Coach. Even Robyn Lawley, an Australian model who is an advocate for body positivity, has been one of the first women above sample size to appear in the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit issue. Modelling has thus come a long way to include people who conventionally faced rejection from this industry obsessed with fair skin and emaciated bodies.

Victoria's Secret's decline in the past few months has somewhat opened the management's eyes that their racial and size bias is no longer going to sit well with consumers. One of the major reasons for its declining popularity is the fact that female customers do not feel included and are tired of the sexy marketing. They have had to lay off 50 people at their headquarters owing to tanking sales and the head of stores and store operations has stepped down amid a failed attempt at a turnaround.

Victoria's Secret has been scrutinised for its lack of inclusivity in the past following former L Brands' Chief Marketing Officer Ed Razek's comments about transgender and plus-size models. L Brands announced that it would cancel the 2019 show in an effort to evolve the marketing of Victoria's Secret. To effect a change in their marketing approach, Victoria's Secret is making sure its new cast of Angels are represented in all of its stores. They have hired their first transgender model, Valentina Sampaio.

Victoria's Secret also announced a recent collaboration with UK-based lingerie brand Bluebella, that has long been dedicated to empowering women, on a collection that 'celebrates inclusivity and strength - each piece is designed for modern, empowered and confident women."

US-China trade war: Dominated trade discussions in 2019

US-China trade war was among the major issue across the global apparel and textile industry. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) has reported that India got an overall benefit of US $ 755 million and Vietnam of about US $ 2,601 million from this trade war.

Right from the beginning of the trade war, Vietnam received more orders from US clients, but the country's industry is concerned about the effects of the influx of Chinese firms escaping tariffs. Chinese companies will directly compete with local companies in terms of labour which will create big pressure on local players. India and Pakistan too get a little share of China and even Bangladesh does not get more comparatively.

Though in India, whenever one talks to apparel manufacturers, very few accept that they are gaining 'something' from this ongoing war or they are able to fit in the cost given by the buyers for orders which are shifting from China to India.

Apart from Indian apparel exporters, even US-based brands are also in dilemma on this issue. Various moves taken by the US Government are seen as a way to mitigate domestic concerns ahead of the 2020 elections. Not only US and China are in loss, but also other countries are left in a confused state due to the frequent changingly conditions and continuous discussion between both the countries.

The United States Fashion Industry Association (USFIA) claimed that the average price of US apparel imports from Bangladesh, India and Vietnam increased by 20 per cent or even more in the first five months of 2019 because companies shifted their orders to these countries.

In 2019, from January to September, India apparel export to US increased by 8.37 per cent (value-wise) and by 5.71 per cent (volume-wise). While India's overall exports of textile and apparel sector (including handicrafts) have increased from US $ 39.3 billion in 2017-18 to US $ 40.4 billion in 2018-19.

Exactly a year after, there is an election coming up in the US and the recent talk between both the countries is moving in a positive direction. Therefore, one can expect that this situation will be finally clear and the 'war' will end. If there is no solution to this 16-month-old trade war, by 2021, US economy may face more challenges as a recession can hit US, while the global economy may face a loss of US $ 455 billion or even more.

Policies specific for apparel industry announced, but little impact

Special package for the apparel industry, demonetisation, GST, change in labour laws are four major policy-level decisions of the Government in recent years have impacted the overall economy as well as the apparel and textile industry. This shows the activeness of the Government also.

On the flip side, forget about National Textile Policy as enough has been said and heard about the same in the last six years, and with 2019 passing by, the Government will again become active on this. But as per industry informed people, it will take at least a few more months in 2020 for the policy to become final. Even apparel exporters are now not that much bothered about this as for them, the major concern is Rebate of State and Central Taxes and Levies (RoSCTL). This WTO-compliant scheme rebates the embedded taxes including central excise duty on fuel used in transportation, embedded CGST paid on inputs, purchases made from unregistered dealers, inputs for the transport sector, embedded CGST and compensation cess on coal used in the production of electricity.

But now the term 'policy paralysis' is used with reference to RoSCTL because this was supposed to come into effect from the date of notification (7th March 2019) and and was supposed to remain in force up to 31st March 2020. But even after 8 months, the industry is still awaiting notification of the same.

It is to be noted that this issue has been highlighted many times in several public forums but its detailed notification is still pending. Industry stalwarts insist that it is not just 5 to 6 per cent that they will get under this scheme; this can be their survival tool as the business is now running on a very thin margin and this incentive really matters. The maximum rate of rebate for apparel is 6.05 per cent while for made-ups, this goes up to 8.2 per cent.

The only positive in terms of policy matter in 2019 has been the initiative of the coming together of various trade bodies/ associations on one platform under the Ministry of Textiles and the Ministry of Commerce.

Moving forward, the Government is releasing the new Foreign Trade Policy (FTP) 2020-25 and the industry is eagerly and positively looking for the same.

Dull year for manufacturing, yet silver linings emerge

2019 was the year of election for India, and as usual, many companies put their expansion plans on hold for a clear picture of the country's overall scenario. Besides, all developments have taken place as usual like previous years. Despite challenges and down sentiments, big and small expansions have taken place.

There are many bigger players who are diversifying within the textile industry, but this will take time that is at least one or two years, due to their individual as well as overall business sentiments. Orient Crafts has kicked off its second large unit at Ranchi and the third is under process. In 2020, many more factories will be operational here as currently, they are under process.

With an investment of Rs. 250 crore, Page Industries also announced to set up a factory in Odisha. As a surprise element, V2 Retail started its manufacturing operations in Noida.

Some of the companies (big ones as well as SMEs) are slowly moving towards their ambitious targets with their unique strategies and they are sure to achieve their targets.

Various states continued their attractive policies to lure apparel manufacturers and MP was also added in this list of 2019. Richa Global, Maral Overseas and Trident Group announced their investment in MP while Avgol, Israel also announced an investment of Rs. 1,250 crore.

Irrespective of the claims made by Gujarat, it is now clear that garmenting is not growing there. And reasons for the same are numerous, at the industry as well as Government level.

Few players which are into textiles and not apparels also announced their entry into apparel production like Kolhapur's well known name Mukta Group of Industries.

SMEs across the nation, continued to add more products, adding small and new factories in established hubs which are comparatively cost-effective like NCR, Noida and Greater Noida. Many new players have also forayed into apparel manufacturing as they are confident about their concepts, planning and resources.

Lesser-known emerging hubs like Indore also went for good expansion. Apparel Online India covered many such companies in 2019.

Investment in automation especially monitoring systems, and implementation of lean and efficiency enhancement continued at a steady pace in 2019. To enhance R&D in apparel manufacturing, Shahi Exports established a Chair in NIFT Delhi which is the first of its kind in the Indian apparel manufacturing sector.

urn:contentItem:5BJY-S831-JCPJ-W427-00000-00Cover story: Will ride-sharing apps be the death of taxis?;Denver now has on-demand services UberX and Lyft offering rides, ordered via smartphone, in networks of owner-driven cars. They say they're more convenient and generally cheaper than taxis, and they're growing fast. But taxi companies feel threatened and are fighting back.2014-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:58ZLexisNexisCover story: Will ride-sharing apps be the death of taxis?Denver now has on-demand services UberX and Lyft offering rides, ordered via smartphone, in networks of owner-driven cars. They say they're more convenient and generally cheaper than taxis, and they're growing fast. But taxi companies feel threatened and are fighting back.Greg Avery

All Brittany Cameron needs are her keys and a phone to become what the taxi industry considers the biggest threat to its business.

The Denver resident drives her Jeep two or three nights each weekend, ferrying other millennial women, and some couples, to nightspots and other destinations. She connects with fares through the Lyft smartphone app that she and dozens of others in the city have started using since it launched in the fall.

It's a social way to earn a little money while meeting people and getting to know Denver, she said.

"I'm just a little part of everyone's night," Cameron said. "It's been fun - the topics of conversation and the energy of people as they're going out on a Friday or Saturday."

Cameron, a former event organizer for the energy industry, drives for San Francisco-based Lyft. Its app matches Cameron to would-be riders and drivers through their smartphones. Cameron's passengers pay through the app using a Lyft account connected to their credits cards. Cameron gets tips plus 80 percent of the fare, while Lyft gets 20 percent.

She, like other Lyft drivers, average two or three fares an hour during busy nights, something that's not lost on taxi companies in Denver and other cities.

Lyft and rival ride-sharing service UberX, plus others not currently in Denver, are providing a growing network of available rides for hire in personal vehicles. Ride sharing is sold as more convenient than taxis, and UberX and Lyft each claim they're between 15 percent to 35 percent cheaper than taxis, though direct comparison of rates is difficult.

These on-demand ride-sharing services have become a big business in a short time.

Lyft, barely 18 months old, handled more than 1 million rides nationally in its first year. Its larger rival, Uber Technologies - which provides apps for Uber Black licensed town-car service and its cheaper UberX ride-sharing service using personal cars - is in 69 cities worldwide, and it's adding a new market every six days.

Uber is backed by Google and some big tech-venture funds, while Lyft is funded by other Silicon Valley tech VCs. Rival ride-arranging apps, such as London's Sidecar have launched in other countries, all using smartphones to out-do taxis.

Taxi cab companies are fighting back everywhere. They've tried hard to get Denver city regulators and the Colorado Public Utilities Commission to crack down on the apps companies for not following taxi industry regulations that hold cabs to defined territories, require them to pick up all passengers and set taxi rates.

A new law proposed at the state Legislature would legalize ride-sharing app service under a new classification of "transportation network company." The bipartisan bill would regulate them for safety - requiring criminal background checks for drivers, set limits for time behind the wheel and establish minimums for insurance coverage.

But, at least in early drafts, the rules would be far more loose than for taxi cabs.

Some see the eventual passage or defeat of the law as a legislative referendum on the fate of Lyft and UberX in Colorado.

The Colorado PUC staff is prepared to slap a cease-and-desist order on Lyft and UberX, saying they don't comply with state laws. The PUC staff will seek support from the PUC's commissioners to shut Lyft and UberX down if Colorado law isn't changed to legalize the services, said Doug Dean, director of the PUC.

"If the legislation fails, we will go out there and start issuing civil penalties and fines and put these services out of business," he said. "It's not our first choice, it's just what we'll have to do."

Even if that's the case, no one interviewed for this story expects ride-sharing app technology to go away. Uber has shown itself to be adaptable, and willing to doggedly press for rule changes that get its services accepted.

Nearly everyone interviewed expects ride-sharing technology to be legalized in some fashion. The question is: Will it be a niche transportation option, or supplant taxis as the dominant way to catch a car-for-hire?

If app-driven ride-sharing in personal cars is allowed, it'll becomes something cab companies will offer, too, predicts Brad Whittle, senior vice president in charge of the Colorado operation of Yellow Cab taxis.

"We might have no choice but to operate like they do," he said.

Dean, the director of the PUC, says he doesn't doubt Whittle means it. He's uncertain regulated cab companies could survive as they are today with a largely unregulated, cheaper ride service growing in popularity.

A lot depends on what kind law, if any, is passed by the legislature: "This could result in de facto taxi deregulation," Dean said.

Cabs, under Colorado law, are licensed to operate in a defined area and charge approved rates, and they can't legally deny service to a paying customer in their service area.

If ride-sharing rules ultimately give cab companies a way out of such obligations, will the poor or elderly still have access to cars for hire? How long will traditional taxi service remain viable?

Some of what the future may look like is already playing out in San Francisco, home city to both Lyft and Uber. There, thorny issues are being sorted about insurance and liability for accidents in the ride-sharing model (see the accompanying story).

San Francisco's taxi and limo companies also have lost a third of their drivers since the arrival of ride-sharing apps, according to research by Forbes magazine. Many are presumed to have gone into business for themselves, using their own cars with Lyft or Uber apps becoming their dispatching service and payment processor.

Ali Vazir, a Denver UberX driver, quit being a cabbie after nearly six years plying streets in Denver for Yellow Cab and Metro. What drew him to UberX was the chance to drop the weekly cab lease payments he made to the cab company, which amounted to $22,000 to $32,000 annually. After other expenses, Vazir said, there were times it was a struggle to make the equivalent of minimum wage.

He, like other UberX drivers, isn't an Uber employee. Technically, he licenses Uber's dispatching and payment software, has to insure himself and his car, and bear vehicle maintenance costs personally. But, Vazir says, his cut of UberX fares brings home more money, his schedule is more flexible, and he drives a newer car, he said.

"I feel emancipated. I'm so much happier, and my passengers are happier, too," Vazir said.

Many cab company drivers see cab companies as decent-paying employers and complain UberX and Lyft are illegal operators that will drive them out of business by being in an unfair position to claim the most profitable cab customers.

Not so, says Uber.

It hired a polling firm, which conducted a phone survey of several hundred registered voters in the 10-county metro area and found that 89 percent of respondents had never used a cab locally.

That jibes with what Lyft driver Brittany Cameron experiences. Her fares are predominantly women, sometimes young couples and occasionally men - and they're almost all people in their 20s or early 30s who don't even think of taking taxis, Cameron said.

"None of my friends take cabs, but they are beginning to take Lyft," she said. "None of them ever took cabs, so it's not like we're taking away their business."

The Southwest Energy Efficiency Project (SWEEP), a Boulder-based energy conservation think tank, is urging the Legislature to legalize person-to-person ride-sharing by app, because it makes not having a car a more viable option at a time when there's a generational shift in transportation priorities going on, especially in U.S. cities.

SWEEP compiled studies that found 33 percent of U.S. 16- to 34-year-olds currently have no driver's license, a post-World War II record, capping a shift away from car ownership that's emerged for nearly a decade, said Will Toor, head of SWEEP's transportation programs. A majority of that age group don't own cars, while smartphone ownership is nearly universal, he said.

The spread of app-driven bike sharing, car-sharing services for short-term rentals, and now ride-sharing services like UberX and Lyft, reflect the rising popularity of sharing transportation and the adoption of car-free or "car-lite" lifestyles.

"There's some fairly strong evidence to suggest that these truly are structural changes," he said."

urn:contentItem:608B-P4N1-JCBF-S31B-00000-00COVID-19 AND CHANGING ATTITUDES2020-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:58ZLexisNexisCOVID-19 AND CHANGING ATTITUDESStates News ServiceLONDON

The following information was released by the Tony Blair Institute for Global Change:

By Multiple Authors

Max Beverton-Palmer

Head of Tech and Society

Andrew Bennett

Policy Analyst, Technology and Public Policy

Rosie Beacon

Policy Analyst

Lizzie Insall

Policy Lead, Renewing the Centre

New Research on Geopolitics, Technology and Social Attitudes

The coronavirus pandemic has had, and continues to have, far-reaching and deep impact on the world. At one point at the beginning of April, it was estimated that more than 3.9 billion people half the world's population were in some form of lockdown. This has been a global crisis, with the actions of China, the United States, the European Union and global institutions such as the World Health Organisation closely scrutinised.

As the world adjusts to the impact of the pandemic, the next phase of our tech work will focus on the geopolitics of technology, building on previous reports looking at the governance and regulation of multinational tech companies, their impact on the global stage and the global architecture surrounding technology policy. We are also continuing our work on 21st-century government, seeking to understand the model of a technology-driven government that delivers for citizens in light of the upheaval of the pandemic.

To build the evidence base for our policymaking, we commissioned four major polls carried out by YouGov in early June in Great Britain, France, Germany and the US. We sought to understand what people in the West thought about the geopolitics surrounding the pandemic, their opinion on global cooperation and how they perceive the role Big Tech should play in tackling the challenges facing the world, and situate that in the context of how they saw the pandemic's effect in their own communities.

The role of technology has also been fundamental to coping with the pandemic, allowing some businesses to continue and people to communicate with their colleagues, friends and families while socially isolated. Much of the technology people have used has been provided by consumer-facing tech companies like Google, Apple, Amazon and Facebook. Their products and services have brought significant benefits for people around the world, but they have also amplified pre-existing harms such as public-health misinformation that has been linked to real-world harm and the spread of hate speech. This has recently led some advertisers to pull spend from social media platforms.

This points towards the coronavirus pandemic having far-reaching impact on geopolitics, on perceptions of technology, and on the development of new views on the nature of community, inequality and social togetherness.

Read the full reports here:

Covid-19 and Changing Attitudes: Technology and Big Tech

Covid-19 and Changing Attitudes: The US, China and Global Cooperation

Covid-19 and Changing Attitudes: Concerns for the Future and Trust

KEY FINDINGS

On perceptions of technology and "Big Tech" companies:

Across Britain, the US, Germany and France, views on whether Big Tech companies are a force for good or bad in the world are mixed, though in all countries surveyed the most popular answer people gave was that they are neither a force for good nor for bad in the world.

Google is consistently viewed more as a force for good than the other companies, and social media companies Twitter and Facebook are consistently viewed more negatively than the other companies.

In Britain, the US and Germany more people see Google, Amazon and Apple as a force for good than see them as a force for bad, whereas more people see Facebook and Twitter as a force for bad than see them as a force for good. In France, only Google is seen as more of a force for good than it is seen as a force for bad (not withstanding that a plurality of people for each company in each country surveyed see the companies as neither a force for good or bad).

Across all four countries, people's perceptions and expectations of the role that Big Tech companies have played or should play, respectively, are closely aligned: People do not see them playing a significant role in tackling the pandemic, nor do they believe that they should. This is in particular contrast to the significant role people expect the World Health Organisation and global pharmaceutical companies to play.

In general, people in all four countries do not expect to work from home more often after the pandemic is over, though roughly a third do in all the countries we surveyed.

All four countries report an increase in shopping online for household goods and clothes, and in particular an increase in online video calls to keep in touch with friends and family. This is especially pronounced in Britain and the US, but less so in France and, in particular, Germany.

Read the detailed findings

On geopolitics and attitudes to the US, China and global cooperation:

Both the Chinese and the US governments are seen as forces for bad in the world by a majority of people in Britain and France, with people in Germany having a worse view of the US government than they do of the Chinese government.

In Britain, the US, Germany and France, more than 40% of people in each country surveyed hold the Chinese government most responsible for the severity of the pandemic, more people than those who hold their own governments responsible.

There is no consistent view on the importance of coordination with other countries on the pandemic, though it is notable that less than a quarter of people surveyed in each country want more integration with the global economy, and in France only 6% wanted more economic integration.

In all the countries we surveyed, people have a much higher expectation of the role the World Health Organisation should be playing in finding solutions to the pandemic compared to the role they think it has played in tackling it.

There are high expectations of global pharmaceutical companies to find solutions to the problems created by the pandemic, but few people have a lot of confidence in those companies (and in France a quarter of people have no confidence at all).

In Britain 60% of people view the UN as a force for good in the world, but the pandemic has changed few opinions of the UN in the countries we surveyed. It's also clear the pandemic has changed few views on the perceptions of the EU in the countries we surveyed.

Read the detailed findings

On the impact of the pandemic on social attitudes and political trust:

Britain has seen a greater surge in community spirit in response to the pandemic than the other countries surveyed.

People in Britain are much more worried about the economy in general than they are about their health. But they are generally as worried about their health as about their own individual economic circumstances.

Across all four countries, more people are more concerned about others than are concerned about their own situation, with worries about families' health and the broader economy more widespread than for individual circumstances.

There is political polarisation as to who bears responsibility for the severity of the pandemic, and who is trusted to address it.

Read the detailed findings

Background to the Research

The source of this data is polling conducted by You Gov of a sample of 8,494 adults in Great Britain, the US, Germany and France. The sample was made up of 2,033 adults in GB between 4 and 15 June 2020; 2,418 adults in the US between 8 and 11 June 2020; 2,020 adults in Germany between 9 and 12 June 2020 and 2,023 adults in France between 9 and 11 June 2020. YouGov is a member of the British Polling Council.

All the research can be found below and we will provide any researchers with the full dataset on request. Please contact max.bp@institute.global

How much will Big Tech benefit — from its dominance and financial strength heading into the pandemic — when we come out the other side?

Substantially — is the accepted view. Smaller rivals will struggle, grow weaker and even go to the wall in the current climate. This will pose a challenge for competition regulators in the future, who will have to look again at breaking up Big Tech’s power and influence. For the present, it already appears to be creating an ethical dilemma for the authorities.

Take today’s decision by the UK’s Competition and Markets Authority to clear a $575m funding round led by Amazon in the UK delivery service Deliveroo, which would give Amazon a 16 per cent stake in the company. It said: “Deliveroo recently informed the CMA that the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on its business meant that it would fail financially and exit the market without the Amazon investment.”

So the CMA, which had been concerned the deal would reduce competition in the emerging grocery delivery market, has cut short its investigation and swallowed its reservations because “wholly unprecedented circumstances have meant reassessing the focus of this investigation, reacting quickly to the impact of the coronavirus and deciding what it would mean for the businesses involved in this transaction and, in turn, for customers.” 

Essentially, Deliveroo failing would have meant less competition anyway, and customers facing higher prices, worse service or being cut off from online food delivery altogether.

As yesterday’s #techFT reported, it was only on Wednesday that the Information Commissioner’s Office said it would go easier on companies guilty of data breaches, due to coronavirus, while the European Commission is struggling to attach privacy and personal data protections to the rapid proliferation of contact-tracing apps. There is a tangible feeling here that regulators are being made powerless by the demands of the pandemic.

Back to the power of Big Tech, and Apple CEO Tim Cook told a company-wide virtual meeting on Thursday that it was still in a strong financial position and he saw no reason not to be optimistic, while Richard Waters’   latest Inside Business column examines the relative fortunes of Amazon, Apple and Google.

The Internet of (Five) Things

1. Netflix eclipses Disney
Another Faang faring well is Netflix, whose value soared past that of Disney on Thursday as its shares hit an all-time high, for a market capitalisation close to $200bn (its shares are down nearly 5 per cent so far today though). Netflix has streaming hits for the lockdown like Tiger King, and while it has shut down work on all of its productions, this is still a golden age for watching TV,   argues Anna Nicolaou.

2. Public support for contact-tracing apps
Nearly two-thirds of Britons are in favour of letting the government use mobile phone apps to track coronavirus sufferers and inform others that they may be at risk, according to new polling commissioned by the FT. Robert Shrimsley is   very excited about the possibilities for these and other pandemic smartphone apps. Meanwhile, Sanofi is teaming up with Silicon Valley start-up Luminostics to develop a coronavirus test that patients could do themselves using   a device plugged into a smartphone. 

3. Getting the message by drone
Two police departments in California have deployed the first “homeless outreach” drones in the US to broadcast coronavirus safety messages while protecting officers.

4. Getting hoax messages by email
Google is blocking around 18m hoax emails about Covid-19 sent to Gmail users every day, while Facebook will   begin showing notifications to users who have interacted with posts that contain “harmful” coronavirus misinformation. 

5. Libra — from world-changer to just another PayPal
After our story on Facebook watering down its payment ambitions on Thursday, Kiran Stacey in Washington and Hannah Murphy in San Francisco have an analysis on how Libra may have little effect on helping the unbanked — if indeed it happens at all.

Tech tools — Dell XPS 13

The main gadget themes during the lockdown have been cheaper smartphones like the iPhone SE and   OnePlus 8 and new notebooks for working from home like the   new MacBook Air and   Samsung Galaxy Chromebook. Here’s another laptop: the latest version of the Dell XPS 13 is still the best Windows thin-and-light laptop,   says The Verge.   Configurations start at $1,199 (£1,399) with its best features being its beautiful, sturdy design, bezel-free 16:10 display and great keyboard and touchpad, marred only by a poor webcam and limited port selection.

urn:contentItem:5YX1-N2G1-DYTH-G0NP-00000-00COVID-19 AND THE DIGITAL LANDSCAPE IN THE GULF2020-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:58ZLexisNexisCOVID-19 AND THE DIGITAL LANDSCAPE IN THE GULFStates News ServiceWASHINGTON

The following information was released by the Middle East Institute:

Mohammed Soliman

While COVID-19 and historically low oil prices are disrupting the Gulf's political economy, the pandemic has demonstrated the region's tech resilience. Since the 2010s, the Gulf has witnessed an upward trend of data outflow and historically high rates of social media and smartphone penetration. Simultaneously, the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) governments particularly those of the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Bahrain, and Saudi Arabia have been directing vast resources toward the digitalization of their infrastructure by creating the needed institutions, amending legislation, partnering with "Big Tech," and building local human capital. The COVID-19 pandemic has certainly been the biggest test of the Gulf's digital infrastructure to date, but the region has proved to have formidable digital resilience.

The UAE

The pandemic caught the world by surprise and caused significant disruption, especially during the transition to remote work. The UAE reaped the benefits of its long-term plans such as the National Innovation Strategy, the Artificial Intelligence Strategy 2031, and the Blockchain Strategy 2021, all of which laid the groundwork for the country's COVID-19 digital response. The transition to remote work, school, and business was recognizably swift, efficient, and resilient.

For instance, Dubai's Paperless Strategy created a digital national identity for 300,000 registered users including citizens, residents, and visitors and gave each an account from which they could access 5,000 nationwide government and private services. The system also enabled the use of digital signatures for documents and transactions, as well as the ability to request and share data with service providers digitally.

Technology played a more significant role in the health response. The UAE's Department of Health developed the TraceCovid app to trace individuals who came into close contact with people later diagnosed with COVID-19. Additionally, Dubai police have a state-of-the-art monitoring system called Oyoon ("eyes" in Arabic), which watches the emirate's 3.3 million residents. With a huge network of cameras in the city, Oyoon uses facial, voice, and license plate recognition to gather data, and feeds the collected information into a shared government database for cross-referencing. To counter the pandemic, this database and network is being used to enforce lockdown rules.

The UAE is known for its data sovereignty doctrine, most notably applied in 2013 when the government blocked access to voice over internet protocol (VoIP) services, including Skype. To counter the economic fallout from COVID-19 and help businesses transition to remote working, the country has lifted its ban on VoIP services, as well as that on the popular video conference apps Teams and Zoom. However, there are serious doubts as to whether the UAE will continue to allow VoIP services after the expected return to the pre-COVID-19 work environment. Unquestionably though, the country will emerge from the crisis more confident in its digital systems and its ability to withstand a global pandemic.

Bahrain

With its continued institutional investment in technology infrastructure and legal frameworks, Bahrain despite its small size and population has steadily grown into a technology hub. To compete with other regional tech hubs like the UAE, Bahrain offers 30-40 percent lower operating costs, in addition to a central location in the Gulf and a tech-savvy population. However, the kingdom gained its position as a sought-after hub for global tech giants because of its regulatory environment, which was the product of decades of reforms: the data protection laws, the bankruptcy law, and the allowance of full foreign ownership in most industries and sectors.

Bahrain is a regional leader in digital infrastructure, as well as one of the first nations to introduce a nationwide 5G network. As a direct outcome of Manama's efforts, Amazon Web Services launched its first cloud center in the Middle East in Bahrain in 2019, adding to the growing list of cloud choices for enterprises in the region.

When the COVID-19 pandemic forced both the government and private sector to shift to remote work, Bahrain's digital infrastructure ensured a swift and resilient transition. The kingdom also brought its digital capabilities to bear on tracing COVID-19 cases. Bahrain's eGovernment launched a contact tracing app called BeAware, which involves infected individuals wearing GPS-tracked bracelets that report to government monitoring stations any movement outside of designated areas. The Ministry of Health may randomly request pictures from self-isolating individuals, who must send back a photo proving they are wearing the bracelet.

The private sector is using Bahrain's strong infrastructure to play a major part in countering the pandemic's economic fallout as well. For instance, MVC Global and Cox Logistics will use blockchain and artificial intelligence to aid in the efficient distribution of food and medicines in the kingdom and the rest of the GCC market. Bahrain's long-term reforms and investments created digital resilience for the government to oversee the transition to remote work, while the private sector had the space to test and deploy its solutions.

Saudi Arabia

Saudi Arabia's investments in technology have paid off in its fight against the pandemic. The kingdom has both the biggest economy in the Middle East and the biggest population on the Arabian Peninsula, but it used to lag behind its Gulf peers in technological development. With Vision 2030, Saudi Arabia initiated a national transformation strategy to shift from an oil-dependent economy to a digitally empowered one. It introduced legislation and frameworks, created institutions, and formed international partnerships. The kingdom also focused on introducing digital solutions in priority sectors justice, health, electricity, culture, and tourism with a clear goal of becoming the region's tech leader.

The Saudi prioritization of digital transformation resulted in the gradual deployment of commercial 5G networks in 2019 in more than 20 cities. The launch of 5G also helped to boost the kingdom's tech credentials among investors who are keen to invest in industries that would benefit from 5G capabilities, such as tech, finance, education, and the public sector. In addition, the government has introduced a host of smart tools that have proved effective and gained the public's trust. For instance, the Ministry of Health updated its app, Mawid, which guides users on self-isolation and hospital visits, while the Ministry of Education utilizes the National Education Portal to provide educational materials and digital tools for students at home.

The pandemic coincided with the Saudi presidency of the G20 forum in 2020. This offered Riyadh an opportunity to lead by example by implementing an early lockdown, suspending the hajj and umrah pilgrimages, and using its position as the chair to coordinate the global response to COVID-19 on various fronts, especially in the digital sector. The kingdom advocated for digital response and recovery, and promoted collaboration with international organizations and the private sector, marking a shift in Saudi priorities. Vision 2030 laid the groundwork for the digital infrastructure that increased the kingdom's digital resilience in the face of the pandemic, and thanks to its G20 leadership Saudi Arabia is now positioning itself as a tech leader in the region.

Conclusion

While the GCC states have not yet transformed from oil-powered economies to fully diversified ones, the reforms carried out and the institutional investments made across the Gulf in the 2010s paved the way for the region's strong digital response to the pandemic and its fallout.

The UAE not only solidified its position as a regional tech hub but also proved that the country is a global digital pioneer. Bahrain, despite being the smallest nation in the Gulf, has emerged as one of its most digitally savvy governments with strong support from local and international tech companies. Saudi Arabia, which lagged digitally behind its Gulf peers despite its vast economy, has benefited from Vision 2030 by creating a resilient digital infrastructure that has withstood the crisis. Additionally, the kingdom's G20 presidency is positioning Riyadh as a strong advocate for the role of technology in countering the pandemic.

Other countries in the Middle East would do well to learn from the Gulf's digital investments when preparing for the future.

Mohammed Soliman is a non-resident scholar with the Middle East Institute's Cyber Program. His work focuses on the intersection of technology, geopolitics, and business in the Middle East and North Africa. The views expressed in this article are his own.

America’s abject failure to deal adequately with the biggest global health emergency in a century has prompted some experts to argue that the pandemic may serve as a geopolitical inflection point. Kurt Campbell and Rush Doshi wrote in March in Foreign Affa...

America’s abject failure to deal adequately with the biggest global health emergency in a century has prompted some experts to argue that the pandemic may serve as a geopolitical inflection point. Kurt Campbell and Rush Doshi wrote in March in Foreign Affairs that just as a bungled intervention in the Suez crisis precipitated the end of the British empire, “the coronavirus pandemic could mark a ‘Suez moment’” for the US, as China “position[s] itself as the global leader in pandemic response.” But even if the effects are not quite that drastic, they will be profound. The US’s declining stature in the wake of the pandemic is accelerating two global political trends that have emerged in the last five years. First, rising tensions between the US and China threaten to initiate a new arms race and a return of great-power rivalry. Second, from Turkey to Brazil to Hungary to Poland, an increasing number of countries are undergoing “autocratization,” centralizing power and restricting political freedoms—putting an end to the post–Cold War waves of democratization that ushered in new freedoms and rights for hundreds of millions of people. Taken together, these two trends will make for a more divided and uncertain world. A global digital divide One visible manifestation of both the decline of US power and the resurgence of autocracy is the fragmenting of the global digital ecosystem. Since Google pulled out of China in 2010 over the government’s censorship of search results, China has cultivated a walled garden of applications primarily for use by its citizens. While the decoupling isn’t total—the Android and iOS mobile operating systems are prevalent, and programming languages like Java and Python are widely used—most Chinese never go on Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, Amazon, PayPal, or many other platforms, but instead use their local alternatives. This fragmentation is part of a larger normative battle. China has been joined by Russia, Iran, and other autocratic regimes in promoting cyber sovereignty —the idea that countries should set their own rules on how their citizens use the internet. In Russia, the government is planning to implement a “sovereign internet,” a self-contained, centrally controlled system that would allow the country to cut itself off from the global internet entirely (see “Yandex’s balancing act,” page 38). By contrast, while the US and Europe differ on the nature and importance of privacy, the limits of free speech, and the right way to regulate Big Tech, there is broad agreement that the internet should be open and interoperable. These trends mean that increasingly, where large countries relied on size, military force, or economic influence, they now also view technology (and not just the military kind) as one of the keys to sustaining and extending their power. This paradigm, known as “ technonationalism ,” rests on two crucial assumptions: first, that an early technological lead gives countries a first-mover advantage, and second, that dominance in certain technologies, such as artificial intelligence, gives them an edge in other fields. These assumptions do not need to be true to be influential. Under their logic, no country can afford to let competitors pull ahead. An illustration of this was the US Commerce Department’s decision in October 2019 to add 28 Chinese companies to its “entity list” of firms subject to trade restrictions. They include most of the leading Chinese AI firms, including iFlytek, SenseTime, and Megvii. Ostensibly, they were added as punishment for facilitating shocking human rights abuses against Muslim Uighurs in Xinjiang. But a secondary result was to hinder them from competing with US companies. More recently, in May 2020, the White House released a strategy document accusing Chinese authorities of exploiting “the free and open rules-based order” and attempting to “reshape the international system in its favor.” It calls for renewed prosecutions of Chinese trade-secret theft and a stronger process for preventing Chinese companies from acquiring advanced technologies, such as “hypersonics, quantum computing, artificial intelligence, and biotechnology.” Subsequently, US officials tightened restrictions against Chinese electronics giant Huawei by blocking the company from using US technology or machinery to manufacture its chips. In late July, the Trump administration abruptly ordered China to close its consulate in Houston, alleging that it was a hub for industrial espionage . China retaliated by closing the US consulate in Chengdu. China, meanwhile, continues to lock out international companies that refuse to play by its rules —such as agreeing to censor search engine results, provide authorities with data on users, or hand over software source code and other proprietary data. It has also ramped up efforts to cultivate “mass innovation” and increase subsidies to strategic sectors such as AI, semiconductor chips, and aerospace through programs like “Made in China 2025.” China also promotes its companies and technologies to many countries in direct competition with US, European, and other firms. Beginning in 2015, Chinese officials began touting the “Digital Silk Road,” focused on internet connectivity, artificial intelligence, the digital economy, telecommunications, smart cities, and cloud computing. This has led to investments in at least 20 countries, totaling nearly $40 billion, according to a 2019 estimate by the RWR Advisory Group, a consultancy. Countries with investments from China’s Digital Silk Road Source: Bloomberg The Trump administration’s attempts to disentangle US technology supply chains from China and its moratorium on new visas for skilled foreign workers, announced in June and extended through December, only serve to help China. A report by Ishan Banerjee and Matt Sheehan published by the Paulson Institute, a think tank in Chicago, found that while Chinese-educated AI researchers produced nearly one-third of all papers accepted at the NeurIPS conference, the leading AI research meeting in the world, most Chinese researchers study, live, and work in the United States. If they are forced to leave, such talent cannot be easily replaced. If Joe Biden is elected president, his administration will no doubt reconsider some of these policies. Jake Sullivan, a Biden campaign advisor, recently said at an event at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace (where I am a fellow) that there should be “less focus on trying to slow China down and more on running faster ourselves.” But whatever Biden does, the competition to determine international norms and standards for critical technologies will continue. The geopolitics of repression Other governments are also using technology to advance their political agendas. Even before the covid-19 crisis, the world was in the midst of an autocratic resurgence. Researchers from the Varieties of Democracy project estimate that 2.6 billion people, or 35% of the world’s population, are having their political liberties curtailed. Authoritarians are using a raft of digital technologies to counter dissent, maintain political control, and stay in power. In my prior research and in an upcoming book, I document how cities in Kenya, Mexico, and Malaysia employ Chinese AI-powered technology to keep watch over citizens; how spyware from Israeli and US sources helps intelligence operatives in Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Egypt monitor dissent and track opposition figures; and how censorship and disinformation campaigns enable authorities in Thailand and Pakistan to tamp down criticism and flood digital channels with pro-government narratives. Countries that possess public surveillance capabilities powered by big data and AI Source: Carnegie Endowment Autocratic regimes are far more likely to use these instruments for repression, but democracies sometimes use them to curb civil rights too. In the United States, for example, the advocacy group Freedom House observes , police have used technologies such as drones, facial recognition, and social-media surveillance in response to escalating Black Lives Matter protests. The pandemic has accelerated this attrition of individual liberties. Data collected by Samuel Woodhams of Top10VPN, a digital privacy group, shows that as of July 2020, 50 countries had introduced contact tracing apps, 35 had adopted alternative digital tracking measures, 11 had implemented advanced physical surveillance technologies, and 18 had imposed censorship related to covid-19. Many of the countries using these techniques are democracies. A big problem is that governments are rushing out health surveillance technology without proper vetting or oversight. Bahrain, Kuwait, and Norway all launched intrusive covid-19 tracing apps that “actively carry out live or near-live tracking of users’ locations by frequently uploading GPS coordinates to a central server,” Amnesty International reported in June. The report caused Norway to suspend its app’s rollout; Bahrain and Kuwait have not. Of course, digital technology isn’t responsible for authoritarianism’s resurgence, but it gives crucial advantages to unsavory regimes . This illiberal assault is putting inordinate pressure on the liberal international order and the institutions that uphold it, including the UN, NATO, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, and others. China and Russia stand to gain the most from this. Indeed, some experts argue that they have directly pursued a “digital authoritarianism” strategy: providing powerful technology to help illiberal leaders entrench their regimes, thereby creating an autocratic alternative to the liberal international order. Source: Michael Coppedge, ET AL. HTTPS://DOI.ORG/10.23696/VDEMDS20 My own research suggests that most of these regimes would pursue anti-­democratic digital strategies even without Russia’s and China’s help. All the same, there is reason to worry about the growing global spread of Chinese technology such as Huawei 5G networks, Transsion mobile phones, and WeChat for e-commerce and communication. Not only does this increase global reliance on Chinese technology, thereby enhancing China’s influence, but many products, such as WeChat’s social app or Alipay Health Code (which classifies users’ health status and determines whether they are allowed to travel or enter certain public spaces), are designed to facilitate government surveillance and censorship. As Christopher Walker, Shanthi Kalathil, and Jessica Ludwig wrote this year in the Journal of Democracy, “The CCP [Chinese Communist Party] has been forging an increasingly seamless synthesis combining consumer convenience, surveillance, and censorship. This model is exemplified by such all-encompassing platforms as WeChat … which includes politically based content restrictions and lends itself to surveillance.” (See also the interview with Samantha Hoffman on page 56.) Of course, technologies are often two-edged swords. Digital tools help civic movements, journalists, and political challengers. The ability of social-media networks to rapidly mobilize citizens and swell mass protests is a potent threat that no regime has fully neutralized. It’s also worth remembering that while the US-China rivalry can dominate discussions about the future of technology, it’s not the only thing determining where trends are headed. The European Union, for example, is increasingly staking out its own independent policy positions . It’s emphasizing privacy, accountability for big tech firms, and transparency for big data and AI. India, Brazil, South Africa, Nigeria, and Indonesia are all deciding whether to try to carve out their own digital agendas or to act more as fence-sitters, playing China, the US, and the EU against one another. Though commentators like Ian Bremmer of the Eurasia Group warn of a “ great decoupling ” between the US and China, with dire consequences for technology, talk of a new bipolar Cold War is overblown. There are too many new players and too many variables to assume that two superpowers will monopolize the rules of technology for the foreseeable future. Instead, we are likely to witness increased splintering as fresh ideas come to the fore, new platforms gain followings, and more people get online for the first time. A multipolar world with new, diverse sources of ideas, innovation, regulation, and geopolitical influence may not be such a bad thing at all.
